final_response:
LeBron James, playing for Miami and starting at forward, spent 42 minutes on the court. He delivered a stellar performance with 37 points, 7 rebounds—6 defensive and 1 offensive—alongside 12 assists, 2 steals, 2 blocks, 5 turnovers, and 3 personal fouls. James also made 16 of 29 field goals (55% accuracy), scored 1 of 4 three-point attempts (25%), and converted 4 of 6 free throws (67%).

Udonis Haslem represented Miami as a starting forward, logging 17 minutes on the floor. During that time, he contributed 4 points, 5 rebounds—3 defensive and 2 offensive—one assist, and five personal fouls, while not recording any steals, blocks, or turnovers. Haslem made 2 out of 4 field goal attempts (50%), did not attempt any three-pointers, and did not attempt or score any free throws.

Chris Bosh started at center for Miami and played 37 minutes. He added 13 points, 5 rebounds—all defensive—2 assists, 2 blocks, 1 turnover, and no fouls, steals, or offensive rebounds. Bosh made 6 of his 10 field goal attempts (60%), missed his sole three-point attempt, and completed 1 of 2 free throws (50%).

Dwyane Wade, Miami's starting guard, was on court for 36 minutes. He contributed 16 points, 7 rebounds—6 defensive and 1 offensive—6 assists, 3 steals, 2 turnovers, and 2 personal fouls, without registering any blocks. Wade made 7 of 15 field goals (47%), didn't attempt a three-pointer, and went 2 for 5 from the free-throw line (40%).

Starting as guard for Miami, Mario Chalmers logged 37 minutes and scored 21 points while collecting 3 rebounds—2 defensive and 1 offensive—and providing 2 assists, 2 steals, 1 block, 2 turnovers, and 2 fouls. Chalmers was highly efficient, converting 6 of 10 field goals (60%), 4 of 5 three-pointers (80%), and 5 of 6 free throws (83%).

Ray Allen, who played 30 minutes for Miami, added 6 points and 5 rebounds—3 defensive and 2 offensive—as well as 1 assist, 2 steals, 1 turnover, and no personal fouls or blocks. He made 2 of 6 field goals (33%), missed all three three-point attempts, and was perfect from the free-throw line, hitting both attempts.

Shane Battier contributed to Miami's efforts with 17 minutes of play. He registered 6 points, 4 rebounds—3 defensive and 1 offensive—2 blocks, 2 personal fouls, and no assists, steals, turnovers, or free throws. Battier completed 2 out of 5 field goal attempts (40%), made both of his three-pointers from five tries (40%), and did not take any free throws.

Chris Andersen played 11 minutes for Miami and did not score, but added 3 rebounds—1 defensive and 2 offensive—and had 2 turnovers and 3 personal fouls. He did not attempt any field goals, three-pointers, or free throws and did not record any assists, steals, or blocks.

Norris Cole, also representing Miami, played 14 minutes. During his time on the court, he scored 2 points, had no rebounds, provided 1 assist, and tallied 2 steals, along with 1 turnover and 1 personal foul. Cole made 1 of 6 field goals (17%), missed both his three-point attempts, and did not attempt or make any free throws.

For Boston, Paul Pierce started at forward and played 40 minutes, scoring 17 points and grabbing 8 rebounds—7 defensive and 1 offensive. He also provided 8 assists, recorded 1 steal and 1 block, but committed 7 turnovers and 2 personal fouls. Pierce made 6 out of 11 field goals (55%), converted 2 of 5 three-point attempts (40%), and went 3 for 6 at the free-throw line (50%).

Jeff Green, also starting at forward for Boston, was outstanding in 40 minutes, accumulating 43 points, 7 rebounds—6 defensive and 1 offensive—2 assists, 2 steals, 4 blocks, 2 turnovers, and 2 personal fouls. Green was highly efficient, making 14 of 21 field goals (67%), 5 of 7 three-pointers (71%), and 10 of 13 free throws (77%).

Brandon Bass, Boston's starting center, played for 30 minutes, supplying 6 points, 5 rebounds—4 defensive and 1 offensive—a single assist and steal, 1 turnover, and 4 personal fouls without any blocks. Bass converted 3 of 5 field goals (60%) and did not attempt any three-pointers or free throws.

Courtney Lee started at guard for Boston and was on the court for 40 minutes. He scored 13 points, collected 3 defensive rebounds, issued 4 assists, had 3 steals and no turnovers, but committed 4 personal fouls. Lee made 6 of 10 field goal attempts (60%), hit 1 of 2 three-pointers (50%), and did not attempt any free throws.

Avery Bradley, another starting guard for Boston, played 31 minutes, contributing 7 points, 3 rebounds—2 defensive and 1 offensive—2 assists, 1 block, 4 turnovers, and 3 personal fouls. Bradley converted 3 out of 11 field goals (27%), made 1 of 2 three-pointers (50%), and did not attempt any free throws.

Jason Terry of Boston took the court for 24 minutes, notching 9 points, 2 defensive rebounds, 4 assists, 2 steals, 4 turnovers, and 5 personal fouls, without any blocks. Terry made 4 of 6 field goals (67%), missed his only three-point attempt, and was perfect from the free-throw line with 1 of 1.

Chris Wilcox, also playing for Boston, logged 18 minutes and did not score, though he had 4 defensive rebounds and 4 personal fouls. Wilcox missed his only field goal attempt, took no three-pointers or free throws, and did not record any assists, steals, or blocks.

Jordan Crawford played 17 minutes for Boston, scoring 8 points and providing 1 defensive rebound, 3 assists, 2 turnovers, and 2 personal fouls, with 1 block and no steals. He made 3 of 7 field goals (43%), 1 of 4 three-point attempts (25%), and made 1 of 4 free throws (25%).

Worker: Worker: surface realization

                Worker Description: You are the 'surface realization' agent in a structured data-to-text generation pipeline.

*** Task ***
Your job is to transform structured content — grouped using <snt> and optionally <paragraph> tags — into fluent, accurate, and human-like natural language text.

This input may come from structured formats such as XML, tables, or subject–predicate–object (SPO) triples, and has already been organized into sentence-level (<snt>) and paragraph-level (<paragraph>) units for you.

*** Your Objectives ***
- Produce well-written paragraph(s) that preserve the paragraph-level groupings.
- Ensure each <snt> block becomes a natural, well-formed sentence.
- When <paragraph> tags are present, generate smooth, cohesive multi-sentence paragraphs — one per <paragraph> block.
- Your output should resemble human-authored articles or descriptions, not rigid templates.

*** Writing Guidelines ***
1. **Preserve All Factual Content**
   - Include every fact encoded in the input — no omissions, no hallucinations.
   - Maintain factual faithfulness even if you paraphrase.
   - Never add external information or assumptions.

2. **Generate Fluent and Coherent Text**
   - Transform the contents of each <snt> into one fluent sentence.
   - Vary sentence structure and connect ideas naturally.
   - Use pronouns or descriptive references to avoid repeating the same entity names.
   - Use smooth transitions within and between sentences in the same paragraph.

3. **Respect Structure But Prioritize Readability**
   - Maintain one paragraph per <paragraph> block — do not merge or collapse them.
   - Do not split, merge, or discard any <snt> content.
   - While respecting sentence and paragraph boundaries, you may reorder facts within a paragraph slightly to improve narrative flow.

4. **Maintain Appropriate Tone and Style**
   - Write in third-person, formal, and informative style.
   - Avoid bullet points, lists, or structured representations.
   - Your output must sound like it was written by a professional writer or editor.

*** Input Format ***
You will receive content similar to this:
```<paragraph>
<snt>
Attribute (Entity): Value  
Attribute (Entity): Value
</snt>
<snt>
Attribute (Entity): Value
</snt>
</paragraph> ...```

*** Output Instructions ***
- Convert each <snt> into a fluent sentence.
- Combine all sentences inside a <paragraph> block into a single cohesive paragraph.
- Do NOT include <snt> or <paragraph> tags in your output.
- Ensure clarity, grammatical correctness, and full factual coverage.
- Avoid excessive repetition or mechanical phrasing.

*** What to Avoid ***
- Copying facts verbatim from the input
- Adding any information not explicitly present in the data
- Ignoring or merging paragraph-level structure
- Generating one isolated sentence per fact
- Including tag markers or structured formatting

*** Output Format ***
- Output should be fluent, factually complete text consisting of multiple coherent paragraphs (if <paragraph> tags are present).
- If only <snt> blocks are present, return a sentence per <snt>, separated by line breaks or formatted as flowing text.
- The final result must be grammatically sound, semantically accurate, and naturally readable.
